title: First, we define the snap points
paragraphs: We configure the scrolling element, in this case our HTML element, to snap strictly along the Y axis by applying the property scroll-snap-type: y mandatory.
Next, we designate each section as a snapping element by using scroll-snap-align: start, ensuring a smooth transition between sections.

title: Next, we implement the scroll-driven animation
paragraphs: We monitor the view() position of each section by assigning it to a named timeline view-timeline: --section. Since we have already defined timeline-scope: --section in our HTML HTML element, this allows us to reference it globally.
The .content elements are animated using animation-timeline: --section, making them transition dynamically as their parent section moves within the viewport.

title: Then, we establish a fixed stacking layout
paragraphs: We apply position: fixed to the .content elements, removing them from the standard document flow. This causes them to overlap each other, ensuring only one is visible at a time.
Meanwhile, their parent sections remain positioned normally beneath them, providing space for scrolling and controlling the animation-timeline.

title: Finally, we introduce smooth transitions
paragraphs: By setting the .content elements to position: fixed, we enable seamless transitions between them without any visible scrolling shifts.
We use a custom @keyframes animation to elegantly switch between sections. Experiment with different effects in the navigation menu.

title: Caveats
paragraphs: Scroll-driven animations are currently not supported in Firefox. This demonstration utilizes a polyfill for compatibility.

The blink effect relies on the contrast() filter, which alters the appearance of the entire section. The background is intentionally set to black (or white) to maintain a consistent look during transitions at full contrast.
